Title: the proton transmogrification

Scene: Sheldon’s bedroom. There is a knock on the door.
Sheldon, dreaming he is in the living room of the apartment on his laptop.
The same, everyone is falling asleep.
Sheldon: Gentlemen, Star Wars Day is rapidly approaching. We should finalize our plans.
Get it?
Come in.
Yes. Actually, I’m glad you’re here. I’m working on the Star Wars Day schedule. Now, I have a window built in after Phantom Menace for complaining, but I’m worried an hour won’t be enough time.
What is it?
Professor Proton is dead?
What are you doing?
Your heart might be in the right place, but your head, chest and arms certainly aren’t.
But, that’s Star Wars Day.
I’m fine.
Hmm. Yes. Look at him, Amy. It’s such a shame. Struck down in the prime of my life.
Oh, I’m not going to the funeral.
All those people blowing their noses. You can’t tell the sick from the sad. Mm. I’ll be at home celebrating Star Wars Day, as planned.
Amy, mourning the inevitable is a complete waste of time.
If we were in a physical relationship, you just lost sex tonight.
Uh, no, thank you.
I’m fine.
Oh, I appreciate the offer, but Arthur is gone and there’s nothing I can do about it. When Darth Vader struck down Obi-Wan, did Luke cry like a baby and go to his funeral?
Arthur Jeffries was a scientist. I’m sure he didn’t care about silly superstitions like funerals. You know, if he were here, I think he’d say enjoy Star Wars Day.
Howard, I think you of all people should avoid espousing the principle that if something is not our favourite we should just get rid of it.

Get rid of the trade route part? Then how would Palpatine get Chancellor Valorum kicked out of office? How would he get himself elected? How? Can we get through one holiday without you saying something ridiculous?
Well, you know what else was just a suggestion? Why don’t we change the Raisin Bran box? Hmm? And you know who got hurt by that? Every single person who eats breakfast.
Look at Arthur, cracking up at a joke I told him. I’ll never hear that laugh again.
Arthur. I thought you were dead.
Why are you here?
I know why. You’ve come to me because you’re my Obi-Wan.
Wow. Uh, you’re dead, so I’m going to let that slide. Obi-Wan Kenobi is a character from Star Wars. After his physical demise, he comes to Luke Skywalker as his mentor in spirit form.
You must be here to give me advice.
Those are your Jedi robes.
Be careful with that.
This is the swampland of Dagobah. It’s where Luke was trained in the ways of the Jedi.
When Obi-Wan came to Luke on this very spot, he gave him all sorts of helpful advice. So, um, what do you got for me?
That’s it? I thought there’d be more of a reason why you’re here.
I suppose it has something to do with your recent passing.
Oh, no. No. I’ve already had to say good-bye to 11 Dr. Whos.
Of course, my grandfather died when I was five. My father died when I was 14.
And now you’re gone, too. It’s like all the men I’ve looked up to have gone away.
But I do appreciate them.
I’m okay. How was the funeral?
I do. After I make them go back and watch one through five first.
That’s true. Oh, it’s a good thing I had a nap.
Wow. A Death Star cake.
You’re back.
That’s nice.
Why do I need you now?
So?
Not at all.
Penny: What? That’s a real thing? What is it, Star Wars Christmas?
So, when is it?
Oh, no. This face wasn’t because I didn’t get it.
Hey, guys.
Okay.
No, thanks. Leonard and I are just going to the funeral.
Oh, I get it, like C3PO. What happened to me?
Sweetie, are you sure you don’t want to come with us to the funeral?
No, he blew up the Death Star. Why do I know this?
Oh, like Attack of the Clones. We are leaving right now.
I have a confession to make.
I’ve never been to a funeral before.
I just never knew anyone that died. I had a pet pig when I was a kid. I mean, when he died, we didn’t have a funeral, we had a barbecue.
I didn’t know him very well, but I still really liked him. It’s weird that he’s just gone.
I feel like I want to cry.
I can’t do it with you staring at me.
No, I’m dry. You’re a big crybaby, you start, I’ll join in.
Toy Story 3?
It was a gift. Thank you for being the emotional one in this relationship.
Yeah.
Well, I don’t want to be a jerk, but it was kind of a bummer.
You think about dying?
What would you regret?
You know Klingon.
No, I meant that as a regret.
What’s that?
Well, it just wasn’t the right time.
And this is also not the right time. Do not propose.
I know that face. That’s your propose face.
What’s two to one?
Oh, my. It’s not a contest.
Okay. Fine. Would you feel better if I propose so you could turn me down again?
Okay. Leonard, will you marry me?
No, don’t you dare. You reject me right now and tie things up.
This isn’t funny anymore. Just say no so we’re done with this. Will you marry me or not?
No.
You know what? Fine. Do whatever you want.
Thank you.
Yeah, he is pretty stupid.
Howard: No. Don’t be ridiculous. That’s Wookiee Life Day.
You sure. Not even coffee? We have R2-Decaf. Maybe a nice Cafe Au Leia?
You’re being so quiet. Are you upset or are you just rebooting?
Since we all agree Episode I isn’t our favourite, maybe we just skip it this time.
Okay, so you’d lose most of Jar Jar, all the trade route talk and the boring senate hearings, which are like watching C-SPAN with monsters.
I think he’s taking this Professor Proton thing pretty hard.
Or should we respect his privacy in this moment of grief?
That’s what good friends would do.
Well, at least without Sheldon here, we got to start with Episode IV.
Boy, some of the physical comedy with Jar Jar is a little tough to watch.
Well, you didn’t miss anything. We just started over.
Leonard: Uh, well, it’s not May the fifth, and it’s not May the third. It’s May the fourth.
May the force be with you. Get it?
Hey, you got a second?
Sheldon, I’ve got some bad news.
I just read online that Arthur Jeffries passed away.
Sorry, buddy.
Comforting you?
Anyway, the, the funeral’s on Sunday.
Yeah, um, of all the things about this that are sad, that might not be number one. You okay? I know he meant a lot to you.
Okay. Yet he cried when they changed the Raisin Bran box.
He was 84, he’d say where’s my pudding?
Hmm?
Really?
Yeah, we won’t be eating Arthur tonight.
I know.
Oh that’s, that’s fine. Go ahead.
Sorry.
I am not a crybaby.

The toys were holding hands in a furnace. Look, Arthur lived a full life. And he inspired a lot of people. Sure, he, he was my childhood hero, but the fact that I got to work with him, side by side, before he died was, it was, it was a gift.
I got your back.
So, what did you think of your first funeral?
Yeah, well, when I die, you can rent a bounce house.
Mm. Well, I think more about if I’d have any regrets.
Mm, you know, that I didn’t travel more, take more risks, learn another language.
That’s true.
I just thought of one more.
I regret not saying yes when you asked me to marry you.
Yeah.
What?
I was not gonna propose. It’s already two to one.
I proposed twice, you proposed once. Two to one.
I don’t know what you’re upset about. I’m the one who’s losing.
Yeah, I think I would.
Hmm.
It’s just such a big decision. I don’t want to have any regrets.
On the one hand, if I say yes…
Ooh, interesting. Did you just propose to me again?
Really? Because I just heard will you marry me? That’s two proposals, one day. Sounds like someone wants to spend the rest of her life telling people how to spell the name Hofstadter.
Hey. Penny, don’t get upset. Here. I love you, but, no, I will not marry you.
Now, about that second proposal. On the one hand…
Hey, buddy. Heard you’re having a rough day. You all right?

It was nice, you know. A lot of people showed up, told some great stories about him. Did you know that Arthur’s son is a high school sci…? (Sheldon hugs him) Hey, the guys are about to start Jedi. You want to go watch?
Sheldon, that, that’ll take us all night.
At least they toned him down in the second one.
Raj: May the fourth be with you?
Hey, Penny. Happy Star Wars Day.
Can I make you breakfast? Admiral Ackbar’s Snack Bar is open for business.
And if you’re not in the mood for coffee I can always make you a Chai Tea-3PO.
Hey, uh, Sheldon, you want anything?
Before you go, at least let me pack you some Attack of the Scones for the road.
Ugh, let’s get this over with.
You know, I heard of this way of watching the movies called the Machete Order, where you watch Episodes IV and V, then skip Episode I, watch II and III as a flashback, and then finish with VI.
Should we try to console him?
By staying here and watching the movie.
Mm, true. I do feel guilty about him.
Maybe we should see how he’s doing.
Hey, we can say it. You can’t.
Amy: Do you want me to go to the funeral with you?
Are you sure you don’t want to go say good-bye?
And watching a bunch of goofy space movies you’ve seen hundreds of times isn’t?
Arthur passing away was harder on Sheldon than he’s ready to admit. Really hoping this will cheer him up.
No, it combines two of Sheldon’s favorite things, chocolate chips and the ability to destroy a planet at the push of a button.
Okay, let’s get the fondant and start decorating.
Did you ever watch Professor Proton when you were a kid?
I never watched him, either, but he seems to be the reason that Sheldon got interested in science.
Oh, I guess it must have been back when I was in the Girl Sprouts.
My mom made it up as an alternative to the Girl Scouts. She didn’t want me selling cookies on some street corner like a whore.
Oh, I went to the library and took out a book on biology to see what whores did.
Yeah. We were hoping it might cheer you up.
Bernadette: Me, too. Although, it might’ve been thoughtless of us to bake a Death Star cake.
Well, anyway, it’ll be a nice surprise for the boys. And Howie doesn’t think I take his interests seriously, so hopefully this will keep him fooled for a while.
This is pretty cool. You don’t see too many spherical cakes.
No. My dad controlled the TV, so unless someone was a Texas Ranger, Jake or the Fatman, we didn’t see it.
Not me. I got into science ’cause I was always the smallest kid in school, so I thought if I became a scientist, I could invent a formula that made me taller.
Yeah, I thought it was working for a while, but then I found out my brother was just lowering the pencil marks on the door frame. How about you?
How did that get you into science?
And even though it meant we had to miss the movies, we could still be part of the fun.
Arthur: You never heard it that time.
I am. Oh, it, it’s fantastic. I mean this, this is the longest that I’ve gone without running into a men’s room in, in, in years.
I don’t know. I was, I was hoping I was going to haunt my ex-wife.
I’m, I’m not, I’m not familiar with that. Is, is, is that an, an Internet?
Well, that, that clears that up.
Well, this, this is weird. Most, most of my robes open in, in the back.
Oh, wait. What, what, what is, what is this?
Oh. Oh. Oh, neato. I’m, uh, I’m going to need a Band-Aid.
Where, where, where are we?
Oh. Too bad. I thought it was Florida.
Um, always, get, get a prenup.
Well, why, why do you think I’m here?
Is, is this the, the first time you’ve lost, you know, someone close to you?
Yeah, I’ve, I’ve outlived a few of my doctors, too.
I’m, I’m sorry about that.
Well, you know, it’s, it’s okay to, to be sad about them. Just, just make sure, you know, you appreciate those who, who are still there for you.
Well, then, what am I doing in a swamp dressed like Friar Tuck? Appreciate them, Sheldon. (Sheldon is woken up by a knocking on his bedroom door.)
Yeah, apparently, um, I’m here whenever, when, whenever you need me.
May, maybe for you.
Well, as near as I could tell, you, you fell asleep watching Star Wars, and now you’re, you’re dreaming you’re watching Star Wars.
I mean, don’t, don’t you see a problem there? I mean, how, how you’re spending your limited time on Earth?
Okay, good luck to you.

May the fourth be with you?
May the force be with you. Get it?
Oh, no. This face wasn’t because I didn’t get it.

I just read online that Arthur Jeffries passed away.
Your heart might be in the right place, but your head, chest and arms certainly aren’t.

And if you’re not in the mood for coffee I can always make you a Chai Tea-3PO.

No, he blew up the Death Star. Why do I know this?

Before you go, at least let me pack you some Attack of the Scones for the road.
Oh, like Attack of the Clones. We are leaving right now.

Okay, let’s get the fondant and start decorating.

I’ve never been to a funeral before.
I just never knew anyone that died. I had a pet pig when I was a kid. I mean, when he died, we didn’t have a funeral, we had a barbecue.
Yeah, we won’t be eating Arthur tonight.
I didn’t know him very well, but I still really liked him. It’s weird that he’s just gone.
I feel like I want to cry.
Oh that’s, that’s fine. Go ahead.
I can’t do it with you staring at me.
No, I’m dry. You’re a big crybaby, you start, I’ll join in.

The toys were holding hands in a furnace. Look, Arthur lived a full life. And he inspired a lot of people. Sure, he, he was my childhood hero, but the fact that I got to work with him, side by side, before he died was, it was, it was a gift.
It was a gift. Thank you for being the emotional one in this relationship.
Sheldon: Okay, here we go. Episode I
Ugh, let’s get this over with.
Since we all agree Episode I isn’t our favourite, maybe we just skip it this time.
Howard, I think you of all people should avoid espousing the principle that if something is not our favourite we should just get rid of it.
You know, I heard of this way of watching the movies called the Machete Order, where you watch Episodes IV and V, then skip Episode I, watch II and III as a flashback, and then finish with VI.
Okay, so you’d lose most of Jar Jar, all the trade route talk and the boring senate hearings, which are like watching C-SPAN with monsters.

Get rid of the trade route part? Then how would Palpatine get Chancellor Valorum kicked out of office? How would he get himself elected? How? Can we get through one holiday without you saying something ridiculous?
Well, you know what else was just a suggestion? Why don’t we change the Raisin Bran box? Hmm? And you know who got hurt by that? Every single person who eats breakfast.
I think he’s taking this Professor Proton thing pretty hard.
Should we try to console him?
Or should we respect his privacy in this moment of grief?
By staying here and watching the movie.
That’s what good friends would do.
Well, at least without Sheldon here, we got to start with Episode IV.
Mm, true. I do feel guilty about him.
Maybe we should see how he’s doing.
Sheldon, dreaming he is in the living room of the apartment on his laptop.
Look at Arthur, cracking up at a joke I told him. I’ll never hear that laugh again.
You never heard it that time.
Arthur. I thought you were dead.
I am. Oh, it, it’s fantastic. I mean this, this is the longest that I’ve gone without running into a men’s room in, in, in years.
I don’t know. I was, I was hoping I was going to haunt my ex-wife.
I know why. You’ve come to me because you’re my Obi-Wan.
I’m, I’m not, I’m not familiar with that. Is, is, is that an, an Internet?
Wow. Uh, you’re dead, so I’m going to let that slide. Obi-Wan Kenobi is a character from Star Wars. After his physical demise, he comes to Luke Skywalker as his mentor in spirit form.
Well, that, that clears that up.
You must be here to give me advice.
Well, this, this is weird. Most, most of my robes open in, in the back.
Oh, wait. What, what, what is, what is this?
Oh. Oh. Oh, neato. I’m, uh, I’m going to need a Band-Aid.
So, what did you think of your first funeral?
Well, I don’t want to be a jerk, but it was kind of a bummer.
Yeah, well, when I die, you can rent a bounce house.
Mm. Well, I think more about if I’d have any regrets.
Mm, you know, that I didn’t travel more, take more risks, learn another language.
No, I meant that as a regret.
I just thought of one more.
I regret not saying yes when you asked me to marry you.
Well, it just wasn’t the right time.
And this is also not the right time. Do not propose.
I know that face. That’s your propose face.
I was not gonna propose. It’s already two to one.
I proposed twice, you proposed once. Two to one.
Oh, my. It’s not a contest.
I don’t know what you’re upset about. I’m the one who’s losing.
Okay. Fine. Would you feel better if I propose so you could turn me down again?
Okay. Leonard, will you marry me?
No, don’t you dare. You reject me right now and tie things up.
It’s just such a big decision. I don’t want to have any regrets.
Did you ever watch Professor Proton when you were a kid?
No. My dad controlled the TV, so unless someone was a Texas Ranger, Jake or the Fatman, we didn’t see it.
I never watched him, either, but he seems to be the reason that Sheldon got interested in science.
Not me. I got into science ’cause I was always the smallest kid in school, so I thought if I became a scientist, I could invent a formula that made me taller.
Yeah, I thought it was working for a while, but then I found out my brother was just lowering the pencil marks on the door frame. How about you?
Oh, I guess it must have been back when I was in the Girl Sprouts.
My mom made it up as an alternative to the Girl Scouts. She didn’t want me selling cookies on some street corner like a whore.
How did that get you into science?
Oh, I went to the library and took out a book on biology to see what whores did.
On the one hand, if I say yes…
This isn’t funny anymore. Just say no so we’re done with this. Will you marry me or not?
Ooh, interesting. Did you just propose to me again?
Really? Because I just heard will you marry me? That’s two proposals, one day. Sounds like someone wants to spend the rest of her life telling people how to spell the name Hofstadter.
You know what? Fine. Do whatever you want.
Hey. Penny, don’t get upset. Here. I love you, but, no, I will not marry you.
Now, about that second proposal. On the one hand…
This is the swampland of Dagobah. It’s where Luke was trained in the ways of the Jedi.
Oh. Too bad. I thought it was Florida.
When Obi-Wan came to Luke on this very spot, he gave him all sorts of helpful advice. So, um, what do you got for me?
Um, always, get, get a prenup.
That’s it? I thought there’d be more of a reason why you’re here.
Well, why, why do you think I’m here?
I suppose it has something to do with your recent passing.
Is, is this the, the first time you’ve lost, you know, someone close to you?
Oh, no. No. I’ve already had to say good-bye to 11 Dr. Whos.
Yeah, I’ve, I’ve outlived a few of my doctors, too.
Of course, my grandfather died when I was five. My father died when I was 14.
And now you’re gone, too. It’s like all the men I’ve looked up to have gone away.
Well, you know, it’s, it’s okay to, to be sad about them. Just, just make sure, you know, you appreciate those who, who are still there for you.
Well, then, what am I doing in a swamp dressed like Friar Tuck? Appreciate them, Sheldon. (Sheldon is woken up by a knocking on his bedroom door.)
Hey, buddy. Heard you’re having a rough day. You all right?
I’m okay. How was the funeral?

It was nice, you know. A lot of people showed up, told some great stories about him. Did you know that Arthur’s son is a high school sci…? (Sheldon hugs him) Hey, the guys are about to start Jedi. You want to go watch?
I do. After I make them go back and watch one through five first.
Sheldon, that, that’ll take us all night.
That’s true. Oh, it’s a good thing I had a nap.
Boy, some of the physical comedy with Jar Jar is a little tough to watch.
At least they toned him down in the second one.
Hey, we can say it. You can’t.
Yeah. We were hoping it might cheer you up.
And even though it meant we had to miss the movies, we could still be part of the fun.
Well, you didn’t miss anything. We just started over.
The same, everyone is falling asleep.
Yeah, apparently, um, I’m here whenever, when, whenever you need me.
Why do I need you now?
Well, as near as I could tell, you, you fell asleep watching Star Wars, and now you’re, you’re dreaming you’re watching Star Wars.
I mean, don’t, don’t you see a problem there? I mean, how, how you’re spending your limited time on Earth?
